My wife and I had reservations for 6:30, showed up about 10 minutes early, and sat in the bar to wait for our friend. They offered us great "bar snacks" while we waited and I ordered a Martini. Got the drink quickly, exactly as i ordered it (although 3 olives is a little much, 2 at the most, 1 is perfect, but I didn't specify quantity) and our friend showed up about 6:28. We chatted and when the waitress came back we told her we were ready to sit, this was probably about 6:35 at the latest. She told the hostess, but we ended up waiting another 5-10 minutes before they sat us, that was a little strange, aka red flag.

So we got seated, met the wait staff but the main waiter didn't introduce himself for another 10-15 minutes. Then he just came by to introduce himself and entertain us, I guess, for a minute. Then another 10 minutes go by and he comes back to show us the steaks, at this point we were already ready to order, and maybe I should have cut him off but it was an interesting presentation so I let him finish.

Then another 10-15 minutes go by before he even takes our order...!! At this point I'm starting to get frustrated but it was my wife's birthday so I didn't want to complain.

So, finally get our order in, and it seemed like this waiter was super busy, but I think he was spending too much time being chummy and entertaining and not enough time waiting and/or managing the other wait staff.

Then the final nail in the coffin, the food takes another 30 minutes and it came cold. I'm sorry but rare steak and scallops don't take 30 minutes. I remained calm because the food was actually good, besides being cold. I had the 12 oz, 35 day aged rib eye, rare, which is still good luke-warm, most steaks cool off by the end anyway. But it started out barely luke warm, my wife later said the scallops were cold. I was in a conundrum. Complain about the cold food, wait for new food, and take even longer, and possibly ruin the night for my wife. At this point we were all ready to leave, so I said nothing.

Also they didn't bring the steak sauces that I asked for until I was half-way through my steak.

Summary: Main waiter was horrible (I'll make him take responsibility for everything), food was cold and I will never go there again.

PS. I gave him a 20% tip too, just to keep appearances for the wife, because I always tip at least 20%, (as long as the service is adequate). If it wasn't for it being my wife's birthday I would have left him $1. I've only done that once before in my entire life.

CUT really surprised me. I don't know what I expected going in, but I guess I'm used to Wolfgang Puck, his manic Euro-accent and his overpriced airport pizzas and didn't expect such a modern and impressively delicious restaurant. 

The decor is very hip but not uncomfortably so -- I didn't walk in and immediately start second-guessing my own wardrobe and sense of cool. It's also tucked away from the casino so you feel like you're in an actual restaurant vs. hearing the ching-ching-bloo-ba-doo-blee-bloo of slot machines in the distance. 

We got seated and waited five minutes at the most for the waiter to come by and greet us/take our order. Not a big deal -- he even acknowledged us right away and said he'd be right with us. We didn't think anything of it, but apparently the staff felt it was a big deal because they offered to comp us two glasses of wine and our dessert at the end of the meal for the "inconvenience." I was blown away by the hospitality. 

But enough about the service, let's get to the food, damnit! I had a kobe beef carpaccio appetizer that was absolutely delicious -- it had great Asian flavors and was mouth-meltingly delectable. The steaks were also fantastic -- they recommend ordering one under what you're accustomed to (I eat medium rare so I ordered a rare) because the steak temperatures can rise due to their cooking methods. My steak turned out perfect. The waiter recommended a pairing sauce but the meat was so good that it didn't need it. For sides we went with the creamed spinach (best I've had at a restaurant) and macaroni and cheese (so good). I can't exactly remember the dessert but it was also pretty good. 

All in all, while CUT is one of the more expensive restaurants I've eaten at, the food quality and service make the cost completely justified. One of the best high-end steak restaurants I've had the pleasure of eating at.

One of the best steaks I've had.  had the rib eye.. it was one of the most tender rib eye steaks I've had.  Corn / cream spinach side dishes were great.  Some of my friends had the filet mignon and they weren't terrible impressed with it.  but... this is about what I ate and i thought my meal was amazing.

Came here with my Wife while we were visiting Vegas. This was our first time at Cut, and the overall experience was great. 
We were seated exactly at the time of our reservation.
Our waiter was fantastic and walked us through the entire menu, describing each dish in detail. 
We were being served a variety of assorted breads nonstop throughout our dinner. 

We ordered the Maple Glazed Pork Belly as an appetizer, it was awesome. Sweet and Savory, exactly right.

For our main dish, we ordered the Japanese Wagyu Ribeye. @ 6 ozs it was $150 and it was worth every penny. This was honestly the best steak we had ever tasted. 6 ozs sounds little, but for the quality you are getting, it is absolutely phenomenal and wouldn't even care to have anymore because it becomes very overwhelming due to the tastiness, juiciness, and tenderness of the meat. Cooked perfectly at Medium. 

We also ordered Pee Wee Potatoes as a side, which were also fantastic. (Soft on the inside and crispy on the outside). Paired well with their 4 different dipping sauces they bring out with your steak.

The grand finale was the Banana Cream Pie. Tasted like heaven in your mouth. All the flavors of the banana, cream, and ice cream were brought together perfectly with the exact amount of creaminess and crunchiness in the dessert. 

Will be back for sure!

Perfect!!!! Service and
Food were amazing. Literally from the moment we walked in... Hostesses were adorable and welcoming, waiters were full of personality with great suggestions. Food was spectacular as well as a great cocktail menu. Wine suggestion with dinner was fab. I'm very impressed and look forward to my next visit! Tuna tartare. Creamed Spinach. Mac and Cheese. Illinois filet. Done and done!

Definitely experienced better and definitely NOT worth the money. 

Key problems:
1) Waiters were good and attentive, but talked a little too much and tried to push the most expensive items too hard.
2) Steaks -- I ordered medium.  I got medium well.  I like medium well and generally dislike sending things back luckily for them.  But when you're paying over $60 for a steak, it should be cooked exactly how you ask for it.  This did not appear to be a one steak problem -- my wife asked for medium and then got medium rare.  Again, she likes it both ways, but pretty much inexcusable at a place like this.  I note that the waiters did NOT even ask us if they were cooked to our liking.  Most good places they'll even watch you cut into it and see what you think.
3) This goes with out saying, but the place is unquestionably overpriced.  If I'm going to pay over $150 per person plus tip, it should be a pretty amazing meal.  This one was good enough, but nothing really wowed me.  

But the kicker was the $8 "Special Occasion" fee added to our bill.  My wife had mentioned it was my birthday that day.  At the end, the waiter asked us if we wanted desert.  We said no thank you because we were too full.  But the waiter decides to bring over a sliver of baked alaska with happy birthday written next to it.  It was a nice touch until we get the bill and were CHARGED $8 for a SLIVER of desert THAT WE DID NOT ASK FOR.  Yes, $8 was a small percentage of our bill.  Yes, I enjoyed the touch of desert.  But bringing someone desert they specifically declined and then charging them is simply unconscionable and totally classless.  That's Vegas for you I guess, fake classy.
Great experience here at CUT! Price matched the quality of food and service and I'll definitely be back on my next visit.

Employees were well trained. The waiter was very knowledgeable when asked about the meat selections. 
Food
- Big Eye Tuna Tartare - 2/5 - wasn't feeling it. I rather have spicy tuna poke from a local poke shop.
- Alaskan King Crab & Carolina Shrimp cocktail - 5/5 - Bomb. Must try. Refreshing.
- American Wagyu Filet Mignon - 5/5 - Must try. Perfectly cooked.
-Another steak (forgot what it was) - 2/5 - Ended up sharing the Wagyu steak with my girlfriend.
-Whiskey cart - Fun little table side service.

Would definitely come back for the Wagyu and Alaskan king crab!

I am a CUT fan.  I've gone to the location at the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills, CA many times, as I've come here as well.

The service is always friendly and attentive.

The food is always excellent.

The prices, well... they're on par with a top notch steakhouse, and expect to pay about $50-100 per person on the steak a la carte, then add in any sides, appetizers, salad, desert and/or drink, and it's easily a $100-200 per person meal.

I always get the American Wagyu New York Steak.

I've had the Japanese Wagyu beef before, which is sort of like Kobe Beef, and is a bit too rich, and the marbleized texture is a bit too oily for me to indulge in more than 2 oz.  It's good, much like how Toro (Fatty Tuna) is tasty, but something you can't eat too much of.  Whereas the American Wagyu is awesome and a perfect notch above standard American NY Steaks, the Wagyu is tender and flavorful, and I recommend getting it done "medium rare"

 It's located in the shopping corridor between The Palazzo and the Venetian towards the entry of The Palazzo.

I hadn't eaten here before but it reminded me of Teemu Selannes near my house. The only thing I would change is making the menu more family style. Here the menu is presented in a way where you feel like you need your own steak and a side or a starter. When it's best to share a larger cut and try a few sides. They had very unique and flavorful bread choices. I had steak three times this week and this was the only place that didn't over cook my steak. It had a nice flavorful seared crust and a large amount of thick buttery red meat throughout the center. A member of the staff brought mustards to try with the steak (apparently this is an Austrian thing) I never ruin meat with sauces. I did try it though and for some reason you can taste both the meat and the mustard independently in your mouth. Still not for me but very interesting. They have very lovely delicate desserts. It's a wonderful treat and I will be coming back. If you're going to stay in a five star hotel you want a five star meal to go with it. This is the place to go.

This restaurant just blows my mind away. From the staff to the food, everything was just amazing. Thank you for making my boyfriends bday, an evening to remember. We can't wait to come back to Vegas for another taste. Cheers!!

Everything was pretty awesome. I had a party of 8 for a bachelorette and they were very accommodating! Our servers (all male, btw) were super knowledgeable in their cuts. I like that they come out and explain with the actual cuts of wagyu. 

Ambiance was very nice, I liked the feel of it.. very open and spacious. You aren't going to be seated too close to anyone here, which is a good thing. Even though they had high ceilings, this place wasn't that loud at all and was easy to talk to people across my table without yelling.

BONE-IN RIB EYE (med-rare) - very tasty, cooked really well

RIB EYE (med-rare) - this was surprisingly better than the bone-in! I've always thought the bone-in would be better since people always say it's tastier, but this rib-eye was reallyyyy good, juicy, and flavor was on point

CREAMED SPINACH - this was ok.. I'm not sure if I was too fond of this. The texture of the egg and the spinach kind of threw me off.

MAC N CHEESE - so good! I'm not huge on mac n cheese but this was one was quite tasty!


All in all, a great dining experience for a very special occasion!

One of the best steaks I've had in my life.

Enough with the complaints about the price though... you KNOW it's going to be expensive when you come here, so be prepared.  I was a bit skeptical when I made reservations because I think WP has over-extended himself in Vegas now... is it 6 restos he has?

That being said, I think he does a fabulous job here.  A group of 5 of us came and the table consensus was that the steaks were amazing.  Awesome decor, very masculine, and I loved the spinning chairs.  the wine list is extensive and excellent... for those on expense accounts, you can have your choice of "esoteric wines" to boot :)

The group ordered a variety of salads to start, and I had the apple salad with walnuts and dates - unique and delicious.  Crisp and tartness in the apples offset with a hint of cinnamon.

For steaks, a variety was ordered around the table including the porterhouse, NY Sirloin and a friend ordered the scallops.  I went for the American Wagyu after the server showed the different cuts (the Japanese Wagyu looked a little too fatty to me).  The steaks were excellent - nicely flavored and well cut.  It was my first time ordering a Wagyu and the meat is a bit fattier than what I'm used to with the marbling, but it was delicious.

The sides were a bit weak - these are served family style here so we had fries (very good), the broccoli (so-so) and the mushrooms (so-so).

It's pricey but I thought it was worth every penny... even my cheap-ass husband agreed, aside from the sides.

Anyone who's also on a low-carb diet should consider forgoing it for the night... there are a few breadsticks to start, but this is followed by a bread service which is excellent.  A server presents a selection of breads on a platter... you MUST try their special bread.  It's got a soft pretzel with salt like taste and is TDF.  Can't wait to come back.

hands down the best culinary experience of my life.

i know i've reviewed a couple of steakhouses, but this place is by far one of the best meals i've had. my fiancee and i were super excited to come here for his birthday dinner, since we're both such steak lovers. 

we were seated the minute we arrived, which was amazing, because typically steakhouses make you wait 10 minutes past your reservation time (i never understood why). immediately, we had our waiter and another server take care of our utensils and water glasses; i can honestly go on and on about how impeccable the service was at this place. they really have all of the fine details down when it comes to customer service, which added to the amazing experience. 

we both started off with caesar salad, which wasn't on the menu, but our waitress was more than happy to have the salads prepared for us. the salad was prepared on butter lettuce, and topped with amazing shavings of parmesan cheese, creamy caesar dressing, and anchovies. you could really taste the quality of the ingredients used. the salad also came with two bruschettas topped with what tasted like garlic aioli, fresh cherry tomatoes, and basil. very delicious! we were also served different types of bread, four different kinds to choose from to be exact, and you could ask for as many as you wanted. 

for the main dishes, we ordered the 35 day aged new york sirloin, 21 day aged bone in rib eye, cavatappi pasta "mac & cheese", and onion rings (no,we couldn't finish it). wow. best steak ever. i definitely couldn't finish it all, but i did save some room for the delicious mac and cheese (i highly recommend ordering this side dish!). i'm not a fan of onion rings, but i absolutely loved these onion rings. the batter was very light and super crisp, which you don't typically find with onion rings. 

since it was my fiancee's birthday, the restaurant provided banana cream pie for dessert. the dish was accompanied with creme brulee, chocolate sauce, and roasted banana gelato; it was rich but super light at the same time.

i highly recommend this restaurant for a special date night or celebration. you will not be disappointed.

Awful. Did I say awful? This place is a real LV stinker. Over hype, overpriced, over full of itself. Whatever you do, don't order fish. I thought the place in Beverly Hills was over the top - with a view of the driveway and unloading vans and limos. Really, a mess in progress.

One of the best dining experiences I have EVER had.
I am not a huge red meat eater...but this restaurant...steak must be tried. Phenomenal service, amazing food and beautiful atmosphere.
Highly recommend as a Vegas local or visitor. You will not be disappointed.

Expensive. Most reputable steak in venetian and palazzo.  I think it it better than delmonico and carnevino.

Decor is more chic than the other two.  Known for having their steak charred and blackened. Quite different than their competitors. Special occasion dining experience due to price.

After seeing every steakhouse repeated from NYC we wanted something new so we settled on Cut. What a great experience.  The server was more knowledgeable then most I encounter in NYC. We went to order a particular cut of meat and the waiter said we would enjoy something better because it was to mineraly. Fantastic sevice, fantastic meal. Highly recommended.

One of regular place to eat when we come to Vegas. Been here about 12 times. Most of times I get medium-rare Nebraska 35 dry aged 12oz Ribeye (tried other cuts but regretted since the rib-eye was so good).  Out of 12 times, one time it was little over done (prob medium) and the other time it was little over-seasoned. But still, steak is really good. 

I still remember the very first bite, which automatically gave me a smile with wow. 

For the appetizers and sides, try to avoid greasy items like fries or onion rings since it will ruin your appetite for meat. 

Level above Mastro's or Ruth Chris.

Best steak I have ever had... hands down... The American Waygu Ribeye had the perfect "salt and pepper char crust" with just the right amount of caramelization. The pork belly appetizer was also very good... as for the sides, this was the only point of disappointment; although good they did not "stand out" as something special as we would have expected from Wolfgang as with the steak. Do not hesitate to try the sauces; a whole grain mustard and house made steak house were a true complement to the already outstanding steaks!

Came here in May for dinner and very much enjoyed the meal. For starters I got the tuna tartare, which was delicious. For the steak, it seems the servers really push wagyu on you. I got the American wagyu filet ($85 for 6 ounces, which is plenty of food for me) with carmelized shallots and cipollini onions. We got sides of the fries, Mac & cheese and kale for the table. Overall the food was good, but I found it a bit over priced.

Loved it!
My husband and I came here on our last night in Vegas as our splurge dinner, it was SO WORTH IT!

This is a place where servers brings by a plate of steak to compare the cuts. There was a tray of bread options as well and a wine list on a tablet. 

The dining room is beautiful, I thought the pillows on the seat was nice. The only thing missing was an outdoor space with a view.

Everything is a la carte here, so be prepared for that. My 28 day aged New York strip was delicious medium rare. My husband's American Wagyu Black Angus hybrid New York Strip was delightful as well. We chose creamed spinach topped with an egg  and fingerling potatoes with bacon as sides. 

I couldn't finish more than about a quarter of the 12oz steak, so the kitchen boxed it up to go with some pretzel rolls to go with room service-eggs the next day.  A great idea!

For dessert, we debated on going to Jean Phillipe at the Bellagio, but wound up staying for blueberry upside down cake.  It was very good, small but sharable, and the plate was dressed with "congratulations" in chocolate :)

We had a nice dinner experience here. Dress-code is enforced here. It's supposed to be a business casual dress so don't show up in tennis shoes. We wore dresses and the guys wore button down shirts. 

We liked everything we ordered:
- Bone Marrow Flan 
- Alaskan King Crab & Carolina Shrimp "Louis" Cocktail
- American Wagyu Beef Sashimi Salad
- Filet Mignon
- New York Sirloin
- Tempura Onion Rings
- Cavatappi Pasta "Mac & Cheese"
- Brussels Sprouts

Go to Joe's Steakhouse in Ceasars Palace and you'll be glad you skipped this joint. Same steak at Joes, Med Rare Ribeye, almost 50$ less and there is no comparison. The steak at Wolfgang's Cut Restaurant was average at best. When you drop 100$ for a steak it should taste unbelievable and should be butter in your mouth. Joe's was. This place wasn't.

We came here on our first night staying in the Venetian and I would give this place 10 stars out of 5 if I could.  EVERYTHING from the service, atmosphere, and food was Perfect!  We paid a pretty penny for our experience here but it was all worth it!!!  Plus when you are Vegas, you throw that budget book out the window as soon as you land.

Let me start by telling you that our servers Ben and Chance were very very attentive and not overbearing and annoying whatsoever.  They catered to our every need and recommended some great selections in our food choices.  Chance even gave us some advice on some great Dim Sum restaurants to visit as well!  They even walk you to the bathroom instead of telling you where it is....pull out your chair for you...and even place your napkin in your laps.  They also bring samples of what the cuts of Meats look like before you order. They have traditional cuts along with expensive Waygu beef for those of you feeling like a high roller.  The service was amazing!

Now on to the food...I eat steak pretty much on a daily basis and go out to quite a few steakhouses. I can tell you that CUT by Wolfgang Puck is THE BEST STEAKHOUSE in Vegas!!! I had a traditional Filet Mignon aged for 35 days medium rare and it was cooked to Perfection!!! It was crispy yet tender.  Juicy but not leaking. It was just...perfect!  I also ordered the Lobster on the side along with Macaroni and Finger Link potatoes and I can tell you that it was THE BEST we have ever tasted.

I will definitely be coming back to CUT next time I am in Vegas!  Wolfgang Puck has definitely put his name on something spectacular!

How could I have forgotten to leave CUT a review?

My first visit was over a year ago on a spontaneous trip to Vegas after Thanksgiving dinner. As if the spontaneity of the trip wasnt enough, my boyfriend said we were going to just have a little dinner after some hands at blackjack. Little did I know he was taking me to CUT! I mustve went to steak heaven because I still havent forgotten how the steak melted in my mouth over a year ago!

We shared a bottle of wine recommended by our waiter which perfectly complimented both my steak and my boyfriend's. The service and food was everything I'd want in a steam dinner.

I assure you that CUT will not fail you. Do go ahead and let your tastebuds splurge!

After my outstanding experience here, it goes without saying that Wolfgang Puck's take on steaks is a "cut" above the rest!

Tucked inside the Palazzo resort, Cut exhibited a refined contemporary appeal and warmth that was both inviting and comforting.  I especially enjoyed the service by Tara who made our visit feel special from the very moment we sat down. 

After allowing us to peruse the menu for awhile, she returned with a cart of steaks and proceeded to give us a brief but detailed description of all their signature cuts and I must say, they all looked enticing! 

Shortly after, we were served our wine and breads, which included the usual steakhouse suspects of fragrant & savory onion focaccia, pretzel roll, one of my personal favorites, mainly because of the firm outside texture and soft and chewy inside... and it wasn't too salty like most other pretzel breads I've come across. 
Parmesan bread stick took a close second  place for its addictive light, crisp & crunchy texture with a generous coating of Parmesan breading on the outside.

Bone Marrow Appetizer - From the buttery soft marrow to the warm, flavorful mushroom sauce, it was a blissful combination of ingredients and love. Simply unbelievable. If there's one single dish from this entire trip, I will be craving for months afterwards, it will definitely be this!

Steak Tasting 
American Kobe Style from snake river - paired with a house steak sauce. The beef was perfectly tender and seared beautifully leaving my mouthwatering for another juicy bite. The tangy flavor of the steak sauce was a perfect addition to the meat as it brought on a bright acidity to the steak. Let it be known, I'm determined to get the recipe for that irresistible sauce!!!!
USDA prime dry aged - much softer and juicier than the New York, this cut of steak was praiseworthy in every way. Honestly, it was a cut of perfection on a plate and the accompanying chimichurri sauce added a brightness to my palate that made it all the more satisfying. 
Australian wagyu from Blackmore -
Worthy of it namesake, was truly the best of the best. It's like they took 50 steaks and concentrated all the beefiness into one bite. The best steak I've ever had. It came with a béarnaise sauce but honestly this piece needed nothing to dress it. It was perfect all on its own.

White corn had a fresh & crunchy bite with a slightly sweet caremelized exterior that added a pleasant rustic flavor to the dish 

Dessert
Baked Alaska - Tasted like a giant strawberry mochi. Btw, that's a good thing!  It also came with a small lemon bar, which had a lip puckering natural citrusy flavor!

Banana Creme pie came with chocolate ice cream, sauce, and chocolate crunch pearls. Now that's what I call a triple chocolate threat! Having said that, It was surprisingly mild and less cloyingly sweet, which I really enjoyed.

Before we left, Tara gave us more sweets in the form of a chocalate truffle cookie bar and a chewy peanut brittle...both were absolutely delicious! 

Service was very thoughtful and the staff in general were ever present without being overbearing. But i'd have to say Tara made all the difference! She transformed a pleasant meal to an unforgettable dining experience with her natural charm and warm tableside manner, which easily made the evening five stars in my book!

Bravo to CUT for an exquisite meal and extraordinary service! 

You bet ill be back for an encore! 

Until then...

Happy Eats!

I have to say If you have been to la location definitely LA is better one. The Vegas location is definitely not as good. As far as service it was superb. Now for food I'd say the menu was not my favorite. The options were not up to my expectations. We had the tuna tar tar it was incredible. The starter breads were alright. I guess nothing beats the warm breadbasket at maestros :/ 
Unfortunately I was looking forward to a Cesar salad but that wasn't on the menu. I mean what steakhouse doesn't have a Caesar !? I had the lamb, which was tasty. My husband had bone in New York also good. Sides were the the pewee potatoes, mac n cheese and Brussels sprouts. The Brussels spouts were soggyyy. We sent back however they failed to send remove it from our bill. We didn't complain but would have been a nice courtesy without us having to say it. The Mac n cheese good your average steakhouse Mac and cheese. The peewee potato was ok little too salty. Would I come back here again, sorry no :(

Their $250 steak is now on our bucket list. We opted for the $68 filet and the rack of lamb. My husband was so pleased with his perfect steak and I too with my lamb. The sides were good too and we can't wait to come back! Delicious!! 

I wish there were more non beef options but it is a steakhouse and once you understand what they're about here you just get it and accept it. I'd love to bring my dad here, and others who can appreciate a perfectly cooked steak.

The CUT beats Craft out in terms of atmosphere and comfort (at least in Vegas). The tables aren't as tight, the service is a bit more on point and I do get a kick out of seeing the bits of cow before it goes in to get cooked. We tried the bone in ribeye and the wagyu tasting trio. Considering how small the pieces of the trio look, you will get full since the ounces do add up. It's hard to eat wagyu while you're eating anything else- the marble meat just melts in your mouth and makes all other meats feel tough and blah. Fatty fatty wagyu, what have you done to me? 

The steaks were good (even the ribeye was decadent the next day, cold but delicious). However if I were to compare the quality, I would say that steakwise, Craft edges out ahead. I felt their cuts were cooked to more of a flavorful end. The ribeye was a little dry (I got medium) and the wagyu was good but lacked the umph that I got from Craft's fabulous skirt. (The Craft's ribeye was good too, but the skirt was amazing for the price.)

Sides were typical, water was refilled and we had a good dining experience. The place gets filled up after 7:30 so reservations are recommended!

I like everything about this place. Great selection of drinks, really cool staff and a bevy of hilarious people that walk through as some are to do in a town so lovely as Las Vegas. I ended up staying here for several hours due to waiting for a very, very late flight...and boy howdy the entertainment from some of the patrons was just so, soooooo memorable. 

The bartenders were cool people, very attentive and am thankful they put up with me for what was wayyy too long....I had nothing better to do, but hey. Scotch. 

I gotta say the presentation for everything is awesome. They had a rather good steak tartare, though nothing too special to be frank. That's kinda the theme of the meal; good, but wasn't living up to any expectations. I won't say disappointing or anything, it just wasn't super exciting. The bread was really good as well, so that was a bonus. 

Ended up with the smaller 10oz NY Strip; it was cooked correctly and had a great sear to it, but I wasn't writing home to momma about it. I liked the meal, I enjoyed the whole thing overall, but I think other steakhouses far eclipse this one that it's tough to want to go back.

CUT is what I envision a steakhouse in heaven would be like. 
In fact, if and when I get to heaven, if there isn't a place like CUT there, I will be extremely disappointed.

We went here for a friend's birthday dinner. We had a reservation, arrived on-time, and were seated promptly. The waiter was extremely knowledgable and attentive. He explained the menu thoroughly and answered any and every question we had. His recommendations were great and his overall demeanor was friendly and nice. When our food arrived he was joined by several other servers who dished out our sides. The overall presentation and service was very good - I felt quite pampered :)

Now onto the main thing - The Food. AMAZING!! The cheese puffs were delicious, as were the breadsticks. The pretzel bread was wonderful too. But the main course was a grand-slam. There were 4 of us, we each got a different cut of steak and we were all in love with what we ordered. We each got a side to share, and I loved them all, especially the macaroni and cheese but MOST OF ALL the creamed spinach and egg. I was the one who ordered the spinach, based on what other Yelpers had said and that dish did NOT disappoint!!! It was fantastic, and I wouldn't have ordered it had it not been so highly rated by others on here, so thanks Yelpers for helping me step out of my comfort zone and try something new there. 

By dessert I was too full for much else, but we got a banana something? and a lemon something? - sorry, I'm being super helpful here, I know - but both were good. But nothing compared with the main meal. It was out-of-this-world delicious.

I should note, here that there was one negative - our waiter forgot our friend's salad. She brought it to his attention, and he apologized and offered to bring it out with the meal, but she declined. But I noticed on the bill that he comped us our desserts, which was a nice touch.

The bill came to roughly $450 or so for the 4 of us, so no, not cheap but worth it! I think everyone should splurge on a fantastic meal every now and then, and I'm glad we did that at CUT. It was wonderful.

My babe and I ate here two nights ago and we were very impressed with Wolfgang Puck's artful steak restaurant.

We arrived and was seated in one of their booths...very comfortable.  It was as if we were sitting on a sofa.  We began the meal by ordering their pork belly and kobe steak sashimi.  The pork belly was simply outstanding......very fatty and super tasty with tangy hoisin sauce.  The kobe sashimi was buttery......very tender.

For our steaks, we had the 10 ounce wagyu rib eye and the 20 ounce bone in rib eye.  Both steaks were awesome...the marbling in the waygu was very fatty.....meaning so flavorful.  For our sides, we had the creamed spinach with an organic egg and herb fries...both very good and blended perfectly with the steaks.

For desert, we had the baked Alaska, banana pie, and date cake.  All three were excellent.....the sweet flavors ended the meal perfectly.

The service was OUTFUCKINGSTANDING!  Throughout the meal, two waiters constantly were at our beck and call.  

A perfect foodie dining experience!

I will start by saying I enjoyed this dinner. However, I did not enjoy it near as much as I did my first visit here.  The staff was great and very attentive. Be careful when choosing wine though. I didn't look at the menu right and ended up getting a $100 bottle on accident!  The good news is that it was great! We started off with the crab and shrimp appetizer. For $31, I would rather have done without it. Too much mayo and weird aftertaste. We got the Mac and cheese side which was awesome and the pee-wee potatoes, which were good but way too salty. I ordered the 35 day dry aged strip. While it was cooked perfect, it was a little too tough and hard to cut. Maybe the dry aging does that? My boyfriend got the American wagyu filet and it was out of this world! Cut like butter and flavor was great! The highlight of the meal was definitely dessert. We got the baked Alaska and I would have licked the plate if it wasn't so classy of a place! Overall I would recommend this restaurant just for the experience alone.

It's all about ambience and service here.  I am usually more impressed by the these aspects of a posh Vegas restaurant but I expect premium food when paying top dollar.  

The location is ideal and the place is happening.  The service is attentive and the sommelier is knowledgeable and precise.  However the bread apps weren't even warm, the sides were not impressive and the steak was over salty and underwhelming.  The sweat beans felt like they were drowned in sugar. The other sides very salty. The steak was an adequate texture slightly undercooked and very very salty.  

I would give it another chance but would probably expect much of the same.

Food is fantastic... then you get the bill... 
Paid $150 for a lobster Mac n cheese that was out of this world... it was more expensive than our steaks. Would I buy it again? NO. 

Would I come back? Yes!

Full disclosure: I have had a massive crush on Wolfgang Puck since I was little - something about the food and that adorable accent - so I was massively excited to try this place.

We each ordered a salad to start, and I had the fresh burrata cheese with prosciutto di Parma, apples & Black Mission figs with micro arugula. I have had innumerable similar variations to this - prosciutto and melon, mozzarella and prosciutto, etc... but this was the single best version I have ever had. Fresh, salty, sweet perfection.

My husband had the heirloom tomato salad with Humboldt Fog goat cheese, white anchovies, and Tuscan olive oil which he seemed happy with. I wasn't paying much attention, frankly, as I was absorbed in soft burrata goodness.

We both ordered the American Wagyu filet mignon - which was FANTASTIC - along with sides of luscious potato puree, and creamed spinach with fried egg (cut in by the server tableside). Jasper ordered a green peppercorn sauce that he never ended up using because the steak was so flavorful. I had some creamy horseradish sauce that was divine. Next time (and there will be a next time) I'd like to top my steak with a bit of bone marrow - yum.

I'm pretty sure that we had chocolate souffle for dessert, but I can't really remember.  That steak was just so darn good!

Great place just a stone's throw from the lackluster Mario Batali offering at Carne Vino. Service is outstanding, steaks are fabulous and the vibe is chic and cool.

Come here for the steaks. They're all good. We've tried most of the offerings and the fliet and bone-in offerings (my go to steaks) are all excellent. Add sauces and sides for extra money to mix and match to your taste. There's no wrong decision here.

Breads, often overlooked at steak houses, are varied and delightful. Just don't fill up and miss out on the awesome meats! Japanese Kobe, American Kobe, American Corn-Fed, Prime and pretty much anything else you can imagine are on tap if you can afford them. We did some tastings of different meats too, little bites basically and some of them ran $60, so be prepared to shell out big bucks for the privilege of dining here.

So, it's a special place and worth the money, just not somewhere you'd want to go as your regular place. There are several expensive wines and several that are decent values if you know your wines or trust the sommelier to ferret out the values for you. Fantastic for a special occasion.

This is by far the BEST steakhouse I have ever been to and will go back (went back already a second time).

First time I was there I had the New York sampler with practically all of it's appetizers.  ALL of which were fantastic...there was not one dish that disappointed me.  the NY sampler consists of 4oz. USDA, 4oz. American wagyu, and 2oz. of the Japanese Wagyu.  I started with the USDA and said "cool"....went to the American Wagyu and said "WOW"...then was on the Japanese Wagyu and said "___"...Yes!!  I was speachless!!  THEE BEST piece of meat I have ever had.  I then tried to eat the USDA and it wasn't even "cool" anymore...so I didn't even bother with that and left it.  Finished the American and saved the best for last....the Japanese Wagyu.  

Went back again in 2 months and I said I was not gonna fool arround this time.  I went straight for the $180 - 8 ounce - Japanese Wagyu.  Again...I was not disappointed and a well spent $250+ dinner.

You must try...

I absolutely loved my experience at CUT during my last visit to Vegas. My friend had been several times before, and said it was a must for our last trip. I was not disappointed. We ate relatively early because we are on East Coast time and it was our first night, and the restaurant was quiet and relaxed.

Our waiter took his time explaining the menu to me, and offered helpful suggestions. I had the beet salad to start, and it was fantastic. Then, I tried the Tasting of New York Sirloin based on our waiter's recommendation. It included a sampling of American Wagyu from Snake River Farms in Idaho, USDA prime aged, and true Japanese Wagyu. Next time, I would just stick with my traditional filet and get the Snake River Farms filet. But for the experience, I'm glad I branched out a tried the sampler, even though I prefer filet.

For a side, I tried the field mushrooms with shishito peppers, and thye were phenomenal. Anytime I see shishito peppers on a menu, I order them. They are my favorite, and CUT didn't let me down.

Of course I was too stuffed for dessert, but I look forward to sampling some of them next time around!

Love the showcasing of the different cuts of meat. You really get to see the beautiful marbling of each piece. I just wonder...what do they do with the meat afterwards? Does the staff get to eat it?? LUCKY.

I ordered the filet mignon, husband got the ribeye. Both were delicious and tender. We also ordered the beet salad and veal tongue appetizers ... definitely recommend! 

I wasn't feeling too good so I decided to get a non-alcoholic drink instead of a cocktail. I got one with really strong thyme/rosemary taste to it and couldn't finish it because it was too aromatic for me. Husband didn't really like it either, so we left it. Just a forewarning in case you're in the same boat as me!

Of course since we were planning on dessert, we skipped on the sides. They have some pretty good desserts so if you have room, make sure to get some!
The wait for the entrees has been way too long. 1h15m since we ordered and the entrees are yet to be served.

This was our one expensive dinner while we were in Vegas.  The bread they bring to the table is to die for and unfortunately we had no self control to stop eating it.  By the time my ribeye and wife's Filet came with multiple sides..we barely wanted to look at food anymore.  Don't get me wrong, it was delicious, but not what you want after an appetizer, bread and a couple drinks.  We were staying at the Venetian and there was obviously nowhere to store it (not that we would have eaten it cold in the morning anyway), but we took it anyway.  Couldn't leave $200 worth of uneaten food for the trash.  Not sure I would come back unless work was paying and even then, I would refrain from bread!

Disappointing. Started off by waiting ten minutes for a table at 10pm on a Thursday - there were plenty open. Once we were seated, the 65 degree temperature really set in, and made for an uncomfortable experience from the start. We had to wait another ten minutes for acknowledgement by a server, and maybe another ten to finally get our drinks served. One of the steaks came out looking like something served at the ballgame, undercooked and didn't even have the signature char on it. My steak was undercooked as well. After initially giving us a bill for the full price, the manager comped the steak, but the damage was done, and we probably will not return for a long time.

We had an excellent experience here!  Not our favorite place to enjoy a steak in Las Vegas, but definitely in the top 3.  This place is worth a visit!

What we got:
- Bone marrow flan- SO GOOD... creamy, rich, decadent bone marrow flavor.  I don't like bone marrow and I LOVED this dish.
- Japanese Pure Wagyu, Miyazaki Prefecture (Ribeye)- Super tasty cut of meat... our only complaint (which was quickly remedied by staff AND the manager came to make sure everything was sorted out) was that it was over seasoned.  I am one that believes that if I am eating a steak of this caliber, it does not need any seasoning... let the beautiful meat speak for itself!  It literally melts in your mouth... so delicious... and reasonably priced compared to the other Wagyu in LV ($30 per ounce).
- Wild Field Mushrooms & Shishito Peppers- we were personally not fans of this side (a bit too saucy)... but we did get a "lucky" spicy shishito pepper!
- Cavatappi Pasta "Mac & Cheese"- pretty freaking good mac and cheese... highly recommend!!
- Grass Fed, Tasmania, Australia Aged 28 Days- this was my steak.  Pretty yummy!

Bread service is odd- you don't get a traditional bread basket, rather, you get individual pieces of bread delivered to your table once you finish each piece.  You get to choose from pretzel bread (yum!), pumpernickel, focaccia and another type that I do not recall.  Butter served with the bread is super creamy and delicious!

Overall thoughts:  Service was outstanding.  We really appreciate the servers and the manager making it right in regards to the steak that we got.  We got complimentary dessert as we were celebrating our anniversary that night.  Cocktails were excellent as well.

This was our first experience at The Cut but it will not be our last. Everything was wonderful. 
The steaks were perfectly cooked, the Wagyu boneless rib-eye melted in my mouth . We had the sauteed mushrooms and brussel sprouts as sides they were also cooked perfectly! The waiter staff was very welcoming and attentive.  
Our best experience on the strip!

Hype. I try to go to a restaurant/establishment at least twice before yelping it, but let's face it, I'm never going back. It's so completely overpriced and waaaay too much beef for one person to eat. The two best things I had on their menu weren't even their "dry aged a million years" steaks. It was the chicken and Kobe Steak Sashimi. I could eat those two things everyday for a year. 

If you're debating between the regular steak and Wagyu, spend the extra money. You can absolutely taste the difference. But both are not worth the money you'll spend here. I honest-to-god feel like I've had better steak at Morton's - tastier, more tender, way better value.

If I could have a re-do at this place I would've ordered family style. It's just not right for a single person to eat that much meat in one sitting. Don't forget to order the Steak Sashimi!

Definitely one of the best meals I've had in Las Vegas! Wolfgang Puck has really outdone himself!

The rub that is used on the steaks is amazing; it was flavorful and not overly salty. The rub really enhanced the perfectly cooked steak. While the steaks at CUT are amazing and so delicious, I was most impressed by the non-beef dishes. The pork chop is probably the best pork dish I've ever had. It was so tender and delicious. I could have eaten several orders of it! The rotisserie poussin is also fantastic. The meat was super juicy and the truffle-laced sauce was so great. I was so tempted to lick the dish clean. 

The best part was the great service. Our server was awesome. He was super professional but not snobby. He kept us smiling all night. 

CUT is definitely now one of my favorite restaurants in Vegas. I can't wait to go back.
Best steakhouse ever. Split the porterhouse for two and I swear the steak melted in my mouth. Better than Mastros, way better than STK. Top drawer service and overall experience. Just awesome.

SOOOO DISAPPOINTED!!! This may be in part because I was expecting this to be amazing so it really fell flat. 

The decor was nice. The service was...interesting--as we had a server in training working alongside our server. Our actual server was great but our trainee completely butchered our meat (and not in a good way). While struggling to sloppily cut our steaks from the bone and leaving half of it still on the bone, he kept inappropriately joking about the meat and bone in an attempt to distract from his lack of skill. Wtf. After he "presented" the meat on the plate in what should have been an appealing display, it looked like someone had chewed and spit the meat onto our plates. I was completely put off but starving and wanted to get back to nurse my daughter.

Between 4 of us we had ordered two of the American wagyu porterhouse steaks (34 oz each) along with the creamed spinach (bland and not very creamy) and French fries (also bland and mushy). They brought breadsticks and a nice selection of breads. Everyone seemed to enjoy it. I didn't have any as I'm gluten intolerant but after inquiring I discovered they have a gluten free sliced bread which was brought out to me 5-10 minutes afterwards. After that came the cheddar biscuit which everyone said was like a bite of heaven. Probably the highlight of the meal. 

When our steaks came out one was significantly smaller and thinner, which is the one my fiancé and I shared. The instant I saw it I suspected we inadvertently had been served the prime porterhouse instead of the wagyu porterhouse but I put the doubt out of my mind since a restaurant of this caliber should not make such a mistake. Boy was I wrong! The meat was not melt in your mouth tender as wagyu should be. In fact, it was really tough, tendonous, not evenly marbled with the fat, and overdone. The servers did not come back for a long time so we just continued eating as we were starving and had to get back to the kids. But when my cousin and I swapped bites near the end of the meal so I could determine if they were the same meat quality I discovered it was most definitely not!!! At that point we had nearly finished everything with no follow up by the servers so I felt it was too late. In hindsight I should have spoken up because when you're paying $200 for a steak you should get what you're paying for.

Maybe I'm spoiled because I've eaten prime, Kobe, and wagyu steaks in NYC, Chicago, Vegas, LA and Dallas...this didn't even come close to measuring up to what I've had as far as the quality of meat, flavor, service and entire experience. It's the most disappointing meal I've had in the past year and a half and that's saying a lot because we eat at a variety of places including hole in the wall and mom & pop establishments. I would never return and never recommend anyone looking for a great steak in Vegas to come here. Choose more wisely than we did and go to any of the other superior steakhouses on the strip.

This is the Wolfgang Puck steakhouse, and supposedly impossible to get a reservation at in LA.  So on a weekend in Vegas, we all decided to try this place out. Sure, it was expensive, but how often do you get to dine out in such a nice atmosphere?

The rooms were dimly lit, and tastefully decorated. We were sat in the inside room, away from the main dining room. Not sure why, but after about 20 minutes I was glad, because our group of 9 quickly became very loud and disruptive (read: drunk).

We first got a choice of maybe 4 different kinds of breads - I tried the onion focaccia and the pretzel, both of which were soooo good. I am a bread fanatic myself, and I have to say, these were amazing! The pretzel was more like a roll with pretzel covering, and it tasted like there was about a stick of butter in the dough - it melted in my mouth. And the focaccia was very flavorful, in just the right way.

The group ordered a myriad of different dishes, which was great because I got to try a little bit of just about everything. I got the porterhouse to share, medium rare like I always get my meat, and it came seared on the outside with a peppery rub, and delicately tender on the inside. It was cooked very nicely. I ended up scraping the meat off the bone... haha.

The scallops, albeit only 4 came on the plate, were exquisite.  I don't know if I would have felt okay with paying about $10 a scallop, but they were definitely the best I've ever had.  I had a bite of the American Wagyu, which was very buttery and definitely tasty.  The japanese wagyu ribeye was even more buttery. They had very high quality beef overall, but some of them came with a little too much salt rubbed on the outside. I don't know if I'd pay $200 for a steak, but it was definitely tasty.

I do have to say, I think my favorite dish of the night was the kobe sashimi - you get 3 thin slices of kobe beef sashimi in a soy sauce vinegarette or something - and it was so delicious. The sides, on the other hand, were just okay. The garlic steam spinach wasn't anything special - I think we would have been better off getting creamed spinach. The mushrooms were good, but then again, I always like mushrooms. We also got some potato side, but I don't remember which it was, and it wasn't all that good.

Most of the food was prepared and presented very nicely. Which is something you would expect out of an establishment like Cut. But service was a little slow and they ran out of the wine that was ordered (I didn't drink it) and had to bring out a different but almost identical one (why couldn't they just notify us in the beginning if they only had one of that kind?). They ended up giving us free dessert at the end of the meal, these teeny bite-sized squares of fudge, cashew, and lemon. The lemon was very tart and was my favorite.

Definitely a great dining experience, but I wish we had gone with a more intimate group. I'd give it 5 stars, but I just don't think there should be any drawbacks in your night when you're paying this much for a meal.

I go to the bar, order a drink and appetizer ... just for the bread. So good.

Order:
Beef Sashimi
Beef tartar
Tuna tartar

Have not had the steak but saving that for a special dinner.

Food is good, not great.  Price is high, but it comes with the location...before money gets to the food, there is the high rent, the hostess, the guy that brings water and bread, the lady that took our order, the other guy that came out to cut our steak...I get it, we are in LV.  But the food, that's what I am here for.  The wagyu is charred outside, they over cooked it.  Asked for medium rare, and beef jerky came out.  the meat has a tough texture, there was still tendon and in the cut.  Very disappointing, they ran out of the bone in Ribeye, so I chose the 35 days aged ribeye.  Surprisingly this is better than their wagyu.  Part of the reason is they didn't over cook it.  The sides are amazing, creamed spinach with eggs, the roasted corn and mac and cheese.

Came here with the BF on the Friday of Memorial Day weekend.  We made reservations for about 10:30pm and the place still had a nice number of people inside but it wasn't crowded at all.

My feedback is as follows:

Service = service was impeccable and lived up to what you expect giving the reputation of the restaurants.  Our waiter did an excellent job explaining the different cuts of meat.  Our water glasses were never empty and the table was always kept clean.  I got a kick out of the iPad menu and ended up playing it with it more than I needed to. 

Food taste/quality = Everything was so delicious!  We ordered:

- Glazed pork belly
- Bone marrow flan
- Bone-in rib eye w/extra marrow on top
- Miso Glazed salmon
- Creamed spinach w/egg (a little too watery)
- Crown & Coke
- Lots of Love martini 
- Kettle One Tonic

Total with tip = $240.00

The only complaint that we had about the food was that when we added the additional marrow to the steak, it was too heavy due to the fatty content and texture.  After a few bites, we almost needed to scrape the rest off to work on the steak.

All-in-all, the place lived up to the expectations.  I have had my fair share of experiences at steakhouses.  While this wasn't the absolute best, it was still very good.

Thank you, Wolfgang Puck.......Meatatarian...... I am!

I'm not real big on giving out 5 stars to steak places and the only other place that gets this honor is Peter Luger's in Brooklyn.  After visit CUT, I realized that it was indeed deserved.

Everything is a la carte. We were a group of six which was nice because we were able to get an array of different side dishes and apps.  Fuji Salad, Crab & Lobster Louis Cocktail and the Tomato salad, there were also some memorable breads.

It was unanimous, everyone ordered "Tasting of New York Sirloin".  We couldn't pass it up.  There was 4oz of USDA Prime, 4oz of American "Kobe" and 2oz of Japanese Wagyu.   Steak heaven.  We chose the onion rings, the creamed spinach, the polenta and the field mushrooms.  The only thing that was terrible was the polenta.... but that's an acquired taste kind of thing.... and I didn't acquire it!

I never in my life wanted to eat steak so slowly as to savor every bite of that Kobe.....until I took a bite of the Wagyu.  It freaking melts in your mouth! It's served in this trio to say, "See how much better it is than your USDA Prime?" and wow is it true.

The decor was very ultra lounge.  I loved it.  Colors worked well, warm tones.  Service was uber professional and very helpful when discussing wines.  I did have a 20 minute wait, even with reservations, but that's to be expected anywhere in Vegas so it didn't even phase me.

I will be back.

Overall...a sensational effort.  From the atmosphere (clean, stylish and modern...but not too cold or sterile) to the food (superb) to the service (attentive and knowledgeable staff)....the dining experience was a memorable one.  I am from Chicago so my bar is set pretty high...and Cut compares favorably with the best steak houses I have visited.

I had a decadent blue cheese wedge salad and the succulent bone in filet...along with a superb bottle of Peter Michael "Les Pavots"...sure...$789 is a lot for dinner for two...maybe the most I have ever spent...but it was most delectable and I dont deduct for costs (since you should know the price range going in)...

A world class steakhouse...

I did not expect such wonderful service and excellent food at this restaurant. I highly recommend it if you love steak. The prices are high but completely worth it. We made a group reservation and they attended us right away. I had the Bone in New York Sirloin. Absolutely delicious! I also like their selection of sample breads that our server was passing around. Would definitely come again if I'm back in Vegas

DON'T GO HERE IF YOU ARE ATTENDING A SHOW THAT NIGHT!!!!  We had been in contact many times before the day of our reservation with the restaurant, letting them know we were attending Phantom of the Opera (which shows in the Venetian, so close by the restaurant) that evening.  We were originally not even going to eat here becuase we thought it may be too much of a time crunch, but were talked in to it by the hostess on the phone, so we consented and made a reservation.  So multiple times they had it in their notes that we had to get out in time for the show.  Then night of reservation, we let the hostess know again on our way in that we were seeing the show later and also let our server know.  And unfortunately, we ended up missing our show, and out over $500 in show tickets, on top of over $600 we just spent on dinner there.  So a +$1,000 evening ruined and frankly wasted!!!  I've been trying to get the manager to call me back to see about getting some kind of compensation as the restaurant caused us to miss the show, and they will just not be considerate and get back to me.  I talked to him once, night of after the fiasco happened and he said he would "assess" the situation and get back to me, and has yet to do so, and we've tried calling him 4 times since, and no return phone call each time because he's "too busy."  So my recommendation, if you want a nice meal out (like we did) before seeing the show, go elsewhere!  **If you see this CUT, it'd be nice to get a call back and get something figured out...I'd be more apt to leave you a better review!**

Amazing food. Especially the chicken skewers and the mash potato. Highly recommended. Honestly we had the best meal in vegas at the CUT. We tried hakkasan, sushi samba and a bunch of other restaurants but the one we enjoyed the most was CUT.

Amidst the plethora of generic steakhouses in Vegas CUT is NOT cut above the rest.  Pun intended.

 I thought the "shock and awe" spectacle of presenting beautifully marbled raw beef of different backgrounds (filet, rib eye, Wagyu, New York) stacked together to stimulate the salvatory glands was a bit kitchy, maybe silly, but somewhat effective.  
 
To start, I ordered the Fuji Apple salad, with bacon lardons and medjool dates.  I had the waiter arrange a wine flight for me, to which he paired a predictable, but delicious, Riesling from Germany.  It was a nice crisp start considering I was in for an incredibly rich meal.

When the waiter presented the raw meat I was smitten with a Wagyu Rib Eye, and demanded it be mine.  I topped it off with bone marrow, and waited like a famished lioness.  I asked the waiter for a spicy red, and he sent me a full and spicy Bordeaux that I couldn't wait to wash down with my meat.  I am a carnivore of the worst kind, and love my meat to be as rare as possible.  For this cut I opted for Medium-Rare bloody, and received medium charred.  The fatty marble goodness I anticipated had evaporated.  What was left was a dry, grey, and chewy piece of meat.  I summoned our waiter, and he was appalled and embarrassed.  His profuse apologies, could not appease me.  I did not yell or make a scene, because that would be counterproductive, and let's be honest, it's not his fault.  I was PISSED at the cook who left that gorgeous piece of meat sitting in the oven too long.  It takes a professional idiot to kill Wagyu, and the lack of respect for a valuable product is unforgivable.  Feeling sorry for me, my mom offered to share her beautifully prepared New York Wagyu while I waited, but I wanted her to fully enjoy her meal, so I snacked on the potato gratin, and asparagus sides as I festered about the ruined meat.  

Our waiter returned with a new piece of meat, more apologies, and offered to comp my meal.  I told him that was ridiculous and unnecessary.  I was angry that a product was wasted, not that I would have to pay for a meal.  What was delivered was sinfully delicious.  Tender, juicy, and melt in your mouth.  The bone marrow was buttery, fatty, and a bit iron-y.  It was great with the beef.  Accompanied by the Bordeaux, it was fantastic.  The sides were pretty forgettable and generic, and maybe that was part my fault for ordering them, but c'mon, protein, starch, and vegetable...how could you mess that up?!

I don't love dessert, but my mom wanted something sweet, so we ordered some chocolate concoction that wasn't memorable.  I had a lovely Spanish Port that I enjoyed more than the dessert.

When we got the bill our persistent waiter had removed my wine, and the dessert.  So I tipped like a Rockefeller, and thanked him anyway.

I'm giving three stars because I do not respect a restaurant that believes it is acceptable to send out an overcooked piece of meat to a customer.  First, you have disrespected the animal, and the purveyor from where that meat originated.  It took hours of work and plenty of money, to raise, feed, clean, massage, slaughter, and ship that animal.  When you disrespect the product you disrespect the entire process it took to get that product on the table, as well as the customer, and your profession as a cook.  Three stars.

Had dinner here w/ a few of my buddies.

Ordered the Wagyu Rib Eye.  I've been to a few high end steak houses(Maestro, Mortons, Flemings, Ruth Chris, Delmonico) and the cut I had is by far the most unique flavor I've ever tasted.  The outside had the perfect charred crisp, and the inside was perfection.  The texture was so different from other Rib Eye's I've tasted.  The inside had the consistency and texture of Sushi.  It was delicate and chewy, and would melt in your mouth.

This might be strange the way I'm reviewing the steak here, but its the only way I can describe it.  Its the best steak, in terms of texture, that I've ever had.  The sides were OK, but nothing to wow about.  I'd recommend saving $$$ by not ordering sides, and just order a larger sized cut.  Had a nice bold Cab to go along w/ the steak which only enhanced the experience even further.

The service was what you'd expect from a high end establishment.  Didn't have any problems, and the timing of the entree's were on the dot.  The decor is more contemporary and sleek, which isn't what you'd expect.  It was very nice inside, but didn't really match the food that they were serving.  Can't really explain it, just go and check it out yourself.

Overall, I'd come back again.  Well worth the $.

...some more please. SMACK!  
Good wine.. Good meat.. Good sides.. Good deserts.. Good espresso. 
You will be broke after eating here. 
Can anyone explain how the bill came up to $2000 (tip incl.) for 4? 
EASY if you are very hungry and thirsty. I think the wine was extra expensive.
I give a 3.5 for good food but the price!
GEEZ!!!!!

got the bone marrow flan as an appetizer.  it is very rich and buttery as some have said.  for the main course got the Japanese Wagyu ribeye.  it was like chewing on cotton candy it was so soft.  for desert, I got the banana cream pie. excellent, rich in flavor but tastes very light.

Wow, three stars? tres estellas? Si! A group of 6 had 8:30 reservations. We were seated, welcomed, shown how to use the ipad/wine list menu. Then we were given the Waygu sales pitch and the marbling explanation. So, we then order drinks, my Mojito was great, get served the complimentary bread sticks which were underwhelming and messy, and finally got to order our cow! I chose the 14oz Nebraska Sirloin (grain fed, why not grass fed cow?) Anyhow, amongst 5 other friends, we all split sides. Fires, whipped potatoes, excellent mac and cheese, and an off the menu selection that our server informed of us......asparagus(it was great!). A friend in our group is/was a newbie to the whole Vegas Steakhouse experience, so I gave him a few pointers. I've read that Cut seems to over season  the steaks and puts a big too much temperature on them. So, order the steak with "light seasoning". Mine was cooked medium rare. While it was a good steak, the seasoning forms a bit of a tough crust, combined with somewhat dull steak knives, the first cut was a bit of a disappointment. 

For desert,  the group split the chocolate souffle, which was excellent and served with a sweet cream and caramel. 

So, why the three stars? I get the ambiance angle, I really do. Its Vegas, its an experience, I have no problem paying that the Vegas rate for a steak is. But, to that end.......the experience is a bit much, it took too long to order our meals and due to that, I had no interest in ordering an appetizer....I just wanted my steak :(

Absolutely amazing. The speciality cocktails are worth the expense. I normally don't fall for the expensive "designer drinks" or "paying for the image" menu but this place can back it up. Food is great and service top notch. Steaks were great. The sauces for the steak over-rated. Meat stands on its own. Prices are premium but hey, it's Vegas. Go for it!

We came here looking for a "Las Vegas Strip Restaurant" experience, and since I've heard of Wolfgang Puck for my whole life and love steak this restaurant fit the bill. We made reservations for 2 about an hour before we arrived on a Thursday night and they were able to accommodate us, although we did have to wait for about 10 minutes to be seated... No big deal we waited in a section near the bar and were offered water/drinks while we waited. As far as the dress code goes- the hostess said "no shorts/athletic wear" but at least on that night most men wore coats and many ladies were in dresses/heels, but you could get by with dark jeans and a nice top. We split the bone marrow flan, 20 oz (I believe this is wet aged) ribeye, and creamed spinach with egg. Breadsticks/bread/ 2 small cheese puffs/ and 2 small one-bite desserts were also served complimentary. The bone marrow flan was really creamy and a very interesting way to start the meal. The steak was good,although not super flavorful( I'm not familiar with this cut as normally I get a T bone which they did not have), it was well prepared. We got the steak sauce and they give different salt/ mustards with it. I would however say that if you want a unique experience it may be worth it to dive into some of there Waygu/dry aged options- I believe they even offer a sampler for around $170 where they give you 3 different cuts. I was worried the egg would be weird with the creamed spinach but it ended up complimenting it rather nicely. The complimentary chocolate and macaroon served at the end of the night made the meal- the flavors and textures were absolutely on point. 
The service also really made the meal, it seemed to me like someone was almost always watching from a distance anticipating every need. Everyone was very friendly and polite and was eager to answer any questions. It was a great experience- although next time I might go for a different steak, this is honestly a personal preference as I was not familiar with ribeye.
They also seem like they can cater to gluten free sensitivities ( gluten free bread etc) if they know ahead of time ( I was told it takes about 10 minutes to get the bread prepared). The bill came to about $120 before tip for two people, and we do not drink, so just be prepared for at least that if not more especially if you get a pricier cut of steak.

I try to go to a different steak house each time I am in Las Vegas and this is the only one I've visited more than once. The American wagyu filet is so flavorful. We also usually get the Mac and cheese and a vegetable. The trio of peas is my favorite. This time we got the broccoli and cauliflower au gratin and it was good. The bread tray is also very appetizing. And don't be afraid to try every piece!

Came here for a bachelor party dinner and our experience was generally positive! This place does things a little backwards it seems. Or I would say the deficiencies are in areas you would not think they would be in.  For instance they took our reservation for 16 and then when we showed up said that we had to sit at two different tables.. which the bachelor was not happy about... Then our table was a round table and it was so rickety. If anyone touched it, it would shake violently. They gave us bread and after we finished eating the bread they decided to bring out the sauce to dip the bread???? And when we asked for more of the pretzel sticks to eat they never brought them out. After 3 separate attempts of asking for them and them apologizing they still never ever brought them???

The little easy things were all wrong, that's what surprised me with this place.

What about the food? IT WAS AMAZING!!!! I had the 16oz bone in Filet Mignon at the waiters suggestion and it was amazing. Cooked perfectly, soft and tender and had an amazing flavor. I tried the Australian Waygu Kobe beef that the bachelor ordered and it was unreal. It was so tasty.  The mac and cheese, fingerling potatoes, mashed potato puree and corn niblets were top notch! I had a 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon and it was very tasty as well. I spent about $110 after tax and tip and it was well worth it.

Now if they can only get the simple easy details right... Like NOT having a rickety old table in a high end dining establishment.

This was my favorite upscale restaurant at The Venetian. We enjoyed the pork belly, beet salad, short ribs, polenta, and lemon meringue pie! Do yourself a favor and order most or all of that, but especially the lemon meringue!!

This place is just a hype. We went here expecting a 5 star steakhouse and sadly we got a 2 star experience. They don't have A1 steak sauce!! What steakhouse doesn't have America's #1 steak sauce? When you are paying $150 for a steak you should be able to chose the steak sauce you want with it, instead of being looked at like your crazy for wanting to put a little A1 on their so called high end piece of meat. 

Then they have a bunch of creepy male waiters wearing all black and when they are serving you, they lean into your personal space. It makes dining a horrible experience. 

For a high end restaurant in a high end hotel on the strip in Las Vegas you would think they would be able to hire a few female waitress so that people don't feel like they are being served by some creepy club security guards! 

As for the rest of the food it was mediocre and definitely not worth $1000 for a party of 4!!

I am only comparing this place to the other high end steakhouses I go to. And this will be one that I will not be returning to.

One of my friends who still lives in Las Vegas, owed me dinner so when I made my way to the high desert for the holidays, he made reservations at CUT so he could pay off his debt. 

Having lived in Las Vegas, I normally stay away from the Las Vegas Strip unless I'm showing someone around, but when it comes to dinner with a friend, and it's steak - you know I'm there! 

I'll start with the service. Everyone should dine here to experience what customer service in the food service industry should be like. I don't know what more to say other than the only way it could be better is if I could just lie on a couch while they hand fed me. 

I've said it before and I'll say it again - food almost always tastes so much better when the service is good. I opted for the Rib Eye and it was so tasty that I inhaled it like it was the first time I ever had beef. It's always nice when you order a piece of meat cooked a certain way and it comes out exactly as you want. To me, the sides were okay and I later was told I should have tried the marrow. 

I'll brave the Strip traffic and all the crowds to come here again. To me, the service alone was worth it.

On the basis of strong recommendations, we chose Cut for my wife's birthday visit. I can say that it lived up to my expectations: if you only have one steak this year, you'll want to order it at Cut.

I opted for the three-course tasting menu, which gives you the chance to sample all thee types of beef. Once you get to the hybrid or Waygu portions, you won't be able to look at the USDA choice the same way (it's sort of like flying first class). Our side was the brussels sprouts, and I started with the beet salad. Dessert was strawberry stratageliata and a chocolate fudge brownie. I'm not a huge dessert person, but these were phenomenal.

About the only thing that detracted from our meal was when a party of six kids dressed in shorts & spray-on tans was led to a nearby table, and we noticed one of them was carrying a six-pack of Coors which was consumed during their meal. Yes, I get it that Vegas does not adhere to strict standards of etiquette, and this group probably had more money than Croesus, but it put a damper on our dining experience. For the amount of money that one pays at Cut, I would think the bar could be raised a bit higher.

My review will strictly be on what I ordered:

Bone Marrow Flan - Probably the best flan I've had thus far.  They had obviously taken the time and finesse to make sure the bone marrow was cooked evenly.  The texture was luscious, melt-in-you-mouth, and rich.  The mushroom puree alongside was fantastic and brought each bite a bit more earthiness.

U.S.D.A. PRIME Dry Aged 35 days - TRUE steak/beefy flavor.  Tasted like a nice steak straight from your own grill, just with a bit more quality to it.  

American Wagyu from Snake River Farms - Fat was nicely marbled throughout, without being too overwhelming.  Great beefy flavor throughout.  

True Japanese 100% Wagyu Beef from Miyazaki Prefecture, Kagoshima - While each bite was TO DIE FOR, I could only handle just a few.  Heavily marbled to the point where that flavor you anticipate from a good steak is lost.  You know that fatty strip alongside a ribeye? That's what the entire steak tasted like.  

Chocolate Souffle - As someone who focuses in patisserie, I was hesitant trying this, given that were were in a steakhouse and typically speciality restaurants lose focus on all other items.  I was wrong.  The souffle was beautiful... light.. airy... yet so decadent at the same time.

OVERALL:  Amongst the 3 steaks I've tried, I prefer the American Wagyu.  It still delivered a marvelous beefy flavor that you want from a steak, while delivering a slight richness from the marbling.  Well balanced in my opinion.  

Like I always say, YOU WON'T KNOW UNLESS YOU TRY IT FOR YOURSELF!
Almost excellent! From appetizer to steak, and wine. Been there several times, almost tried every course on menu, except tones of wines there. One of the best in Vegas!

Want to make a grown man sob like a baby?  Tell him that the steak is so good at CUT that it ruined you for any steak thereafter....then take him to CUT and watch as he licks his lips, takes a long sip of his expertly chosen Bordeaux and eagerly slices into his $130 piece....of fat and grizzle.

Then have the waiter smash some glasses on two of your guests and focus on cleaning the mess instead of apologizing to them.

Then clear my plate while my back is turned so I can't ask the waiter if the guest chef tonight is smoking crack.

Will I give them a second chance?  Of course.  Will I get psyched up before I go?  Not this guy.  CUT is a serious place so I'll chalk all this up to a "series of unfortunate events".

We really enjoyed our meal at Cut.  Service is impeccable and they never rushed us and educated us on the different styles of steak. I would recommend the Mixed Emotions cocktail.  Mac and cheese and cauliflower were both great sides.  The star of the meal was the steak l, as you would expect.

Another great meal in Las Vegas!  A friend of mine and I had a great experience Monday night at CUT.  I started with a glass of champagne and we shared the butter lettuce salad with a champagne vinaigrette...simple, but delicious.  We both enjoyed the wagyu beef filet and it was melt in your mouth good, but very rich.  We shared the creamed spinach and mac 'n cheese sides...both of which were sinfully good too.  I don't think you can go wrong at CUT.  However, this place isn't cheap, so come prepared to spend a mini fortune for this culinary treat!

This is the second time I visited Cut and both times have been very good experiences - once in the restaurant and once just at the bar for some appetizers. The food is as you would expect, inventive and adventurous. Not everyday you get to try steak of this quality. 
It is missing the fifth star because the food, while very good, it isn't THE best in Vegas. Also, the service is very, very Vegas - snooty without class, make you wait in line outside the club even though their is no one inside kind of crap. Not everyone there is like that, but enough of them are (especially at the hostess stand) to make it annoying.

King for a day!  

The Cut is rather expensive, but you are pamered throughout the day.  The Kobe steaks are rich and tender.  The service is superb and make you feel wanted. 

Overall, a great experience at the Cut and certainly worth it if you are willing to pay the price.

I have eaten here before and decided to go again with some friends.  It started out very well as everything came out as expected.  I love the bone marrow appetizer.  We had the lobster mac and cheese side dish with our steaks since it was the special along with a couple others.  I should really have asked the price of the special side dish beforehand.  The bill came and the lobster mac and cheese was $108???  I had to look at it twice to make sure I wasn't seeing things.  I have had the lobster mac and cheese at other steakhouses (Capital Grille, Chicago Cut etc).  Never were they more than $25-$30 so I thought somewhere in that range is what it would cost.  I brought this up to the waiter and he basically said in a condescending way, yes, that is the price.  I was fuming at this point.  When a side dish costs $108, perhaps you should mention that to the diner before letting them order it.....I believe this would come as a shock to anyone.  Our steaks averaged $69 each and a side dish costs $108.......this was a tremendous oversight or failure by the restaurant in my opinion.  The manager did reduce the price to $54 after I mentioned something to her.  Kudos for trying to remedy the situation, but even at $54 it seems pricey let alone me having to complain about the original $108.  It really made what would have been a great meal awful.
